PATIENT SUMMARY:
========================
___ hx ESRD ___ DM nephropathy) s/p failed DDRT at ___ in ___ 
(failed I/s/o disseminated adenovirus infxn in ___ on HD 
___, T2DM, HTN, C. diff, HFrEF, PAD s/p multiple vascular 
interventions and recent R BKA who was recently admitted for B
fragilis bacteremia and stage III sacral ulcer, discharged to 
rehab then re-presented s/p fall on ___ with AMS, hypotension 
and leukocytosis with course complicated by ongoing poor mental 
status despite completing treatment for infection and right 
middle cerebellar peduncle infarct thought unlikely to explain 
mental status. Transferred from the MICU to the medicine floor 
on ___ given resolving sepsis likely from sacral wound. He was 
stable on the medicine floor with waxing and waning orientation 
(likely his new baseline) requiring intermittent dialysis, pain 
medicine, and anti-itching medicine.

ACTIVE ISSUES
=============
#Intubation d/t mental status
#Hypercarbic respiratory failure now resolved
#Chronic Aspiration
Patient intubated ___ for airway protection iso worsening 
mental status. Multifocal opacities on CT Chest concerning for 
aspiration pneumonitis vs pneumonia.  Discussions with wife 
throughout course indicated that he would want everything done 
including trach/PEG if necessary; however of note he would 
require C-surg d/t complicated anatomy. He had a prolonged 
intubation due to excessive  secretions and poor mental status. 
He was able to be extubated ___ and did well. His diet was 
advanced slowly which he tolerated well. Diet at discharge was 
soft solids, thin liquids, with 1:1 supervision.

#Toxic metabolic encephalopathy
#Epileptiform discharges on EEG
#Altered mental status
#CVA - right middle cerebellar peduncle
Mental status was poor despite completing treatment for 
infection above. EEG over multiple days not consistent with 
seizure like activity. MRI brain revealed small punctate infarct 
in right middle cerebellar peduncle; however, this is unlikely 
to explain mental status. MRA with patent circle of ___ 
arteries. Patient received keppra 500 BID with extra 500 post 
dialysis on MWF. He received atorvastatin and ASA for CVA risk. 
Plavix was held in setting of bleeding. Neurology and vascular 
surgery both agreed that Plavix can be discontinued. 

# ESRD on ___ HD: 
Received CRRT due to hypotension; renal followed. Patient was 
transitioned back to MWF HD without complication. Requiring 
midodrine TID for hypotension. 

# History of B fragilis blood stream infection
# Chronic Stage IV Sacral Ulcer
# Septic shock
# Leukocytosis
# Multifocal Pneumonia
Initially leukocytosis with AMS and HD instability c/w septic 
shock. S/p abx for b fragilis ___ sacral wound. CT A/P, CT Head 
x2 negative CT Chest ___ revealing multifocal opacities w/ air 
bronchograms. CT findings likely represent inflammatory changes 
related to multiple aspiration events. Required levophed for 
hypotension as well as high dose midodrine. s/p Vanc, ceftaz, 
flagyl empirically ___ - ___. Fecal management system 
(flexiseal) placed to divert stool from open sacral wound and 
help with healing. Would need diverting colostomy for definitive 
wound repair, which wife states is absolutely NOT within GOC. 
Wound care and ACS followed, recommended enzymatic debridement 
and ultimately placed wound vac. Plastic was not offering flap 
for closure given comorbidities. On ___, pressor requirement and 
white count increased, started vanc/meropenem again given 
blue-green drainage from wound; wound culture grew pseudomonas. 
He finished course of meropenem on ___. Patient also received 
stress dose steroids in the setting of sepsis. He remained 
stable without any other signs of infection through his hospital 
stay.

# Anemia
# Hematochezia 
Chronic anemia due to renal disease, trended downward ___, with 
CT C/A/P without evidence of bleed. Stool dark and guiac 
positive making GI bleed most likely. Patient was too unstable 
at present to undergo scope. Had visualized melena and 
hematochezia earlier in admission iso likely hypotension/bowel 
ischemia which had resolved but bleeding seems to have recurred 
while on asa/Plavix for CVA. Plavix was held and hemoglobin 
remained stable. Endoscopic evaluation was deferred. Patient 
received PO lansoprazole twice daily for two weeks. He had no 
more episodes of GI bleeding through his stay and he was 
transitioned to his home famotidine 20 mg daily. Hemoglobin was 
stable on discharge. 

# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
Patient was on insulin gtt in the ICU and transitioned to basal 
insulin glargine 16u with Humalog insulin sliding scale.

#SVT (resolved) 
#Likely MAT
Appeared to have MAT on EKG while in MICU. Has intermittent 
episodes of SVT into the 130s while on dialysis. Blood pressure 
has been stable without any symptoms noted during episodes. Rate 
control is being deferred given soft blood pressures and issues 
with hypotension during HD. 

CHRONIC/RESOLVED ISSUES
=======================
#Nutrition: Began home tube feeds which was advanced

#Transaminase elevation: He had a mild transaminase elevation 
last admission in ___ thought to be ___ drug effect from 
antibiotics." Known to be HCV positive but not active given 
negative surface antigen. No thrombosis or sign of chronic liver 
disease on RUQUS. No hx of new drugs that would likely cause 
DILI. Intermittently hypotensive and likely ischemic 
hepatopathy. Resolved.

# PVD: Held atorvastatin initially due to liver injury, 
restarted atorvastatin after liver function normalized per 
neurology recommendations given vascular disease. Held 
gabapentin throughout his hospital stay due to mental status.

#Gout: Continued allopurinol which was changed to every other 
day dosing on ESRD.

Dear Mr. ___,

surgery was uncomplicated. You spent some time in the Intensive 
Care Unit for close monitoring. Unfortunately after your surgery 
you developed an ileus, or slow movement of your bowels, which 
resolved on its own. You also had a urinary tract infection 
requiring a course of intravenous (or IV, through your vein) 
antibiotics. In addition, your LDH was high concerning for a 
clot in your LVAD and you received anticoagulation with a 
bivalirudin drip to treat the clot. Your level of 
anticoagulation on warfarin subsequently increased to an 
appropriate level, so your bivalirudin was stopped.

Moving forward: 
-You should continue to take the medications below as written. 
-If you notice any changes in the readings on your LVAD device, 
you should contact your cardiologist immediately.

urologist with instructions and information about your surgery 
and post-operative plan of care.

infection through ___.

that you NO longer need to take medications that shrink your 
prostate (Hytrin, Avodart, Flomax, etc.)

Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 4 grams (from ALL sources) PER DAY.
-For your safety and the safety of others; PLEASE DO NOT drive, 
operate dangerous machinery, or consume alcohol while taking 
narcotic pain medications.

household chores are generally ok.  Fold laundry but ___ 
lift it. Wash/Dry dishes. Do not Vacuum. 
-resume regular home diet and remember to drink plenty of fluids 
to keep hydrated and to minimize risk of constipation. 
-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting 2 days after an egg 
retrieval, concerning for ovarian hyper stimulation syndrome.  
Initial pelvic ultrasound showed enlarged ovaries bilaterally, 
with normal dopplers.  There did not appear to be a large amount 
of drainable pelvic fluid.  She was initially found to be 
hemoconcentrated, with a hematocrit of 50.  She also had mild 
hyponatremia and a transaminitis.  She was started on 
cabergoline for a 10 day course (___-).  She also received sub 
cutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis in the setting of 
hemoconcentration.  She required IV dilaudid and PO oxycodone, 
on top of tylenol and ibuprofen, for pain control.  She was 
noted to be tachycardic to the 110's, so she was monitored on 
telemetry without arrhythmias.  Labs were trended.  Repeat 
ultrasound on ___ was stable.  

Due to persistent abdominal distention, nausea, and abdominal 
pain, she underwent therapeutic paracentesis on ___, during 
which 3 liters of fluid were drained.  Gram stain of her fluid 
was negative - cultures were preliminarily negative (pending at 
time of discharge).  She also received 50 g of albumin on 
___.  Her symptoms of abdominal distention drastically 
improved following paracentesis.  Her diet was gradually 
advanced, and she required no narcotic pain medication.  
Initially, following the procedure, she was hypotensive to the 
the high 80's/40's and tachycardia to the 110's, but she was 
asymptomatic from a cardiopulmonary standpoint and EKG was 
notable for normal sinus rhythm.  Her vitals improved once she 
PO hydrated.  EKG was notable for normal sinus rhythm.  She was 
kept on telemetry, which was reassuring.  Her urine output, 
which was low prior to the procedure, improved with PO 
hydration.  Her labs were trended throughout her stay - her 
hematocrit downtrended, and her hyponatremia and transaminitis 
were stable.  

By ___, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding 
spontaneously with adequate urine output, ambulating 
independently, and pain was controlled with oral, non narcotic, 
medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition 
with outpatient follow-up scheduled for ___ (also for repeat 
labs).

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the gynecology service for abdominal pain. 
you were diagnosed with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. You 
had a pelvic ultrasound which showed enlarged ovaries 
bilaterally. You underwent paracentesis (draining of the fluid 
that collected in your belly) and were observed with improvement 
in your symptoms. The team feels it is safe for you to be 
discharged home. 

Please follow these instructions:
* Pelvic rest - nothing in the vagina for at least a week, 
unless cleared by Dr. ___.
* Limit oral fluid intake to less than 2 liters per day (less 
than a few regular sized water bottles) - this will help 
decrease the fluid in your belly. 
* Use Tylenol and Ibuprofen as needed for abdominal discomfort. 
Use Zofran as needed for nausea.
* Do not eat or drink anything after 6am on ___, 
before your follow-up appointment with Dr. ___.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* significantly worsening bloating or abdominal fullness
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Care Of The Surgical Incision:
- You have absorbable sutures in place, which do not need to be 
removed. 
- There are Steri strips over your surgical incision. Please 
leave them in place. If they have not fallen off after 14 days, 
you may carefully peel them off.
- You may shampoo your hair. Let the water run off the surgical 
incision. Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs along 
the surgical incision.
- Do not use creams or ointments on your surgical incision. Keep 
it clean and open to air.

Activity:
- No heavy lifting for 1 month. Then slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace.
- No driving until cleared at follow-up.
- Do not operate any motorized vehicle or drink alcohol while 
taking narcotics.
- No sexual activity for 1 month.

Common Problems:
- Pain and loss of sensation over the surgical incision should 
resolve over the next ___ months.
- Swelling at the surgical incision should resolve over the next 
few weeks.
- Fatigue will slowly resolve over days to weeks.
- Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high fiber diet. You may also try an over-the-counter 
stool softener if needed.

Please Call Your Neurosurgeon At ___ If You Experience:
- Severe pain, redness, swelling, or drainage from the surgical 
incision.
- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Worsening headaches.
- Lethargy, nausea, or vomiting.
- Changes in vision, such as blurry vision, double vision, half 
vision, loss of vision, etc.
- Slurring of speech or difficulty finding the correct words to 
use.
- Stiff or painful neck.
- Difficulty swallowing.
- Difficulty moving or using your arms or legs.
- Difficulty feeling in your arms or legs.
- Any problems with your medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On POD#1, the patient had urines sent for an elevated white 
count.  Urines were negative.  She was given a bolus of 500 mL 
of fluid for an elevated heart rate.  Her heart rate remained 
elevated on POD#2.  Her hematocrit was 22.7 and she was given 2 
units of blood. Her post transfusion hematocrit was 28.9. In the 
morning of POD# 3, her hematocrit was 29.8. 

On POD#3, patient's discharge was postponed due to intermittent 
tachycardia. Per medical records in ___, patient has occasional 
HR in the 100's but primarily in the 60-80s. The patient denied 
any chest pain or difficulty breathing. An EKG was obtained 
which showed HR 102 and sinus tachycardia. The patient's case 
with discussed with medicine who recommended placing the patient 
on telemetry monitoring to evaluate for paroxysmal atrial 
fibrillation. Her oxygen saturation was 95-97% on room air. She 
was afebrile. 

On POD#4, medicine was formally consulted who recommended a CTA 
to rule out a PE for persistent tachycardia. The CTA was 
negative for PE.  HR improved with better pain control and 
hydration. 

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The overlying surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the 
Silverlon dressing was found to be clean and intact without 
erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by 
physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. 

Ms. ___ is discharged to rehab in stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your ___.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep apply dry sterile dressing daily to 
your knee wound if your wound is still draining. If your wound 
is dry, you may leave it open to air without any dressing.  It 
is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup.  Check wound regularly for signs of infection such 
as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by 
at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize with assistive devices (___) if 
needed.  Range of motion at the knee as tolerated. No strenuous 
exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

12. You were evaluated by the Medical Team while ___ for an 
increased heart rate.  Please schedule a follow-up in 1 week 
with your Primary Care Physician for continued evaluation.

segment internal carotid artery with flow seen distally. 
2. Occlusion of the left M1 segment just distal to the carotid 
terminus with essentially no signal of the left MCA branches. 
3. Moderate to severe multifocal atherosclerotic disease 
throughout the circle of ___, most pronounced in the 
cavernous internal carotid arteries and right posterior cerebral 
artery. 
4. No evidence of acute infarction or intracranial hemorrhage. 
5. Small bilateral left greater than right cerebral convexity 
subdural fluid collections/hygromas.  No significant mass 
effect. 
6. Chronic infarcts in the bilateral basal ganglia and pons. 
7. Mild parenchymal volume loss and probable moderate to 
extensive chronic 
small vessel ischemic disease. 

___ RIGHT UPPER EXTREMITY VENOUS ULTRASOUND
Extensive deep venous thrombosis involving the right subclavian, 
axillary, and one of the paired brachial veins.  Notably, the 
right subclavian, axillary, and brachial veins are were occluded 
on ___ right upper extremity ultrasound. 

___ CTA HEAD AND CTA NECK 
1. No acute intracranial hemorrhage or territorial infarct. 
2. Stable left convexity hypodense 2 mm subdural collection. 
3. Corresponding to findings on MRA, there is near complete 
occlusion of the right internal carotid artery in the petrous 
segment with flow distally and patent right MCA arborization. 
4. Severe stenosis and likely complete occlusion of the left M1 
segment at the carotid terminus although there does appear to be 
flow distally in the MCA arborization possibly due to 
collaterals. 
5. Approximately 40 to 50% narrowing of the bilateral 
supraclinoid internal 
carotid arteries due to calcified atherosclerotic plaque. 
6. The posterior circulation appears patent without significant 
stenosis. 
7. Approximately 50% narrowing of the left internal carotid 
artery in the 
cervical segment by NASCET criteria. 
8. Right lung opacities suggest infectious or inflammatory 
process. 
9. 9 mm cavitary nodule in the right upper lobe could suggest 
tuberculosis, 
septic embolus, or malignancy. Dedicated chest CT recommended. 
10. Markedly enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. 

___ CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST
1.  Multifocal opacities involving right upper/middle lobes and 
left lower 
lobes, right greater than left with sparing of the left upper 
lobe suggest a multifocal infectious process predominantly 
centering along airways and 
peribronchovascular parenchyma.  Additionally there is a small 
but new 
peripheral nodule with cavitation in the right upper lobe.  
Atypical organisms should be considered for this in addition to 
bacterial pneumonia.  New lymphadenopathy in the mediastinum in 
each hilum. 
2.  Persistent occlusive venous disease in the right upper 
extremity. 

___ TTE
The left atrial volume index is SEVERELY increased. There is no 
evidence for an atrial septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is normal 
left ventricular wall thickness with
a normal cavity size. There is mild-moderate left ventricular 
regional systolic dysfunction with XXX (see schematic) and 
moderate global hypokinesis of the remaining segments. No 
thrombus or mass is seen in the
left ventricle. Quantitative 3D volumetric left ventricular 
ejection fraction is 35 % (normal 54-73%). Due to severity of 
mitral regurgitation, intrinsic left ventricular systolic 
function is likely lower. Left ventricular cardiac index is 
normal (>2.5 L/min/m2). There is no resting left ventricular 
outflow tract gradient. Normal right ventricular cavity size 
with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. Tricuspid annular 
plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is depressed. The aortic sinus 
diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta 
diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal with a 
normal descending aorta diameter. The aortic valve leaflets (3) 
are mildly thickened. There is no aortic valve stenosis. There 
is no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets appear 
structurally normal with no mitral valve prolapse. There is 
moderate mitral annular calcification. There is moderate to 
severe [3+] mitral regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the 
severity of mitral regurgitation could be UNDERestimated. The 
pulmonic valve leaflets are not well seen. The tricuspid valve 
leaflets appear structurally normal. There is mild to moderate 
[___] tricuspid regurgitation. There is moderate pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
regional and global left ventricular systolic dysfunction most 
consistent with coronary artery disease or other diffuse 
process. Moderate to severe mitral regurtitation. Moderate 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Right
ventricular free wall hypokinesis. Compared with the prior TTE 
(images not available for review) of ___, the estimated 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure is now increased. 

CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: The patient's LVEF is less than 40%; a 
threshold for which they may benefit from a beta blocker and an 
ACE inhibitor (or ___ and a mineralocorticoid receptor 
antagonist.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
====================
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
==================== 
___, ___, with h/o ESRD on ___ HD, type II 
diabetes, asthma, peripheral vascular disease, stroke, coronary 
artery disease, HFrEF EF 35%, atrial fibrillation on warfarin 
who presents with generalized weakness, fevers and epistaxis 
found to have supratherapeutic INR, hyperkalemia and 
community-acquired pneumonia. Given cavitation seen on CT chest 
and history of untreated latent TB, he underwent TB rule out 
which revealed 3x negative smear and negative TB nuclear acid 
amplification test. Course was c/b acute-on-chronic RUE DVT, 
toxic-metabolic encephalopathy, hypoxic respiratory failure 
secondary to flash pulmonary edema, which all resolved by 
discharge. Anticoagulation was changed from warfarin to 
apixaban. Rehab was recommended given significant deconditioning 
and pt/family ultimately agreed.

==================== 
ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==================== 
#Cavitary lung lesion
CT chest shows cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. His 
TB risk factors include being from an endemic country and 
requiring chronic HD, latent untreated TB. However, AFB smear x3 
negative, and TB NAAT was negative. Cultures were pending. Per 
discussion with Infection Control, patient is at insignificant 
risk of having TB infectivity. TB precautions were stopped 
in-house. Infection Control will follow up re: TB cultures. 
Respiratory symptoms were felt to be consistent with patient's 
CAP (per below).

# Community acquired pneumonia
Initially on CTX/azithro, at one point broadened to 
vanc/cefepime in the setting of hypotension, then narrowed back 
to CTX/azithro for total 5d course given overall clinical 
picture. Speech and Swallow evaluated patient and felt him to be 
low risk for aspiration.

# ESRD on HD (MWF)
# Hyperkalemia
# Hyponatremia
# Hypervolemia
# Hypoxic respiratory failure
# Hypotension
Secondary to missing 2 HD sessions. K 6.8 on admission. Received 
urgent HD. Later in admission, developed flash pulmonary edema, 
requiring again urgent HD. Later, triggered for hypotension to 
___ systolic after HD secondary to UF, improved with IVF. Had 
some intermittent hyponatremia which was managed with HD. By 
discharge, had received consistent ___ HD which he was 
tolerating well.

# Supratherapeutic INR
# Acute on chronic extensive RUE DVT
Presented with INR > 13.8. Reversed. Once INR dropped, patient 
developed RUE DVT, with ultrasound showing extensive DVT 
involving the right subclavian, axillary, and one of the paired 
brachial veins. Per initial Hematology recommendation, bridged 
with heparin then transitioned back to warfarin, goal INR ___. 
It was difficult to achieve a stable INR during his hospital 
course and after discussion with renal team, transitioned him to 
apixaban 5mg BID. He was discharged with 1 month supply.

# Toxic metabolic encephalopathy
# Transient aphasia
# Multifocal intracranial stenosis
Patient had apparent transient expressive aphasia on ___ in the 
setting of receiving dialysis. However this was difficult to 
assess given concominant delirium, metabolic derangements and 
requirement for ___ language interpreter. Neurology was 
consulted and Code Stroke was called with reassuring workup. CT 
head, MRI/MRA brain, and CTA head/neck which did not show acute 
stroke, but did demonstrate severe intracranial atherosclerotic 
disease. Home atorvastatin was increased to 80mg. Continued on 
home aspirin 81mg.

# Diabetic retinopathy
Neuro team noted monocular diplopia. He was followed up by 
ophthalmology on ___ who noted moderate bilateral cataracts and 
moderate-severe diabetic retinopathy. Recommended follow up in 
ophthalmology clinic.

# Rehab needs:
Severely reconditioned.  Pt originally refused transition to 
rehab preferring to return home with family.  Ultimately, pt 
agreed to plan for rehab as he recognized that he could not 
manage at home until he gets stronger.

# Heart with failure reduced ejection fraction (EF 38%)
# Ischemic cardiomyopathy
# Mild/moderate [___] TR
# Severe (3+) MR
# Atrial fibrillation 
TTE was repeated this admission due with EF 35%, 3+ MR, ___ TR. 
Volume managed with HD. Continued on home metoprolol. Digoxin 
held while on azithro, resumed afterward. He is not on optimal 
medical therapy for HFrEF. Per last cardiology note, he was 
initiated on low-dose captopril previously but had hypotension 
on HD days, then it was held and on another visit recommended 
restarting it and holding on HD days. Did not restart while 
inpatient due to hypotension after HD, would resume if able as 
an outpatient. Anticoagulation per above.

# Dyspnea/Chest tightness
Patient complained intermittently of dyspnea which was thought 
multifactorial from fluid overload, deconditioning, and asthma. 
EKGs were not concerning for active ischemia. He was treated for 
asthma as below.

# Constipation
Started on bowel regimen which was uptitrated to miralax BID and 
2 tabs of senna BID, then started having loose stools. 
Discharged with daily miralax. Please monitor.

# Elevated Lactate
# Respiratory alkalosis

respiratory alkalosis and lactate of 8 which decreased without 
intervention, thought possibly related to poor renal clearance 
vs. type D from frequent
nebulizer treatments.

# Leukocytosis
Intermittently elevated to 10 range, thought iso infection and 
inflammation.

# Asthma
Continued albuterol prn and fluticasone BID. Put on standing 
DuoNebs, transitioned back to home regimen at discharge with PRN 
duonebs. ___ benefit from outpatient PFTs.

without compression, osteomyelitis, or epidural abscess. Most 
consistent with exacerbation of radicular pain

# Peripheral vascular disease

ISS while inpatient.

Continue omeprazole.

H/H stable.

Brief Hospital Course:
- ICU COURSE - 
Ms. ___ is a ___ s/p mechanical fall with radiographic 
evidence of grade ___ splenic injury. She was hemodynamically 
stable with stable hct without need for transfusions. However, 
given the extent of injury, the patient underwent prophylactic 
central splenic artery coiling by Interventional Radiology. No 
extravasation was seen during the procedure and the patient did 
well post-procedure. She remains hemodynamically stable and her 
hct was 28. Repeat hct was the same. As such, the patient was 
written for a regular diet and transferred to the floor. 

She remained A&Ox3 throughout ICU course. Pain was minimal. 
Cardiovascular functions were monitored noninvasively. Pulmonary 
toilet was encouraged with incentive spirometry.  Her fluid 
balance was recorded and electrolytes were repleted 
appropriately. she was afebrile. The patient was then 
transferred to the surgical floor. 

- FLOOR COURSE -
The patient's HCT remained stable at 26.4 x 2.  Vital signs were 
stable.  The patient was restarted on her home blood pressure 
medication.  Pain was controlled with oral acetaminophen.  She 
remained alert and oriented throughout hospitalization.  She 
remained stable from a cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, 
early  The patient tolerated a regular diet. Patient's intake 
and output were closely monitored
The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.  Subcutaneous heparin was 
held and ___ dyne boots were used during this stay and she was 
encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.  The patient stated she would 
prefer a follow-up appointment with a General Surgeon closer to 
home and that she would arrange this.  She was also provided 
with the ___ clinic number.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ after 
a fall and were found to have a splenic injury.  Given the 
extent of the injury, you underwent splenic embolization by 
Interventional Radiology to stop and prevent further bleeding.  
You tolerated this procedure well.  Your blood counts have 
remained stable, you are tolerating a regular diet and your pain 
is better controlled.  You are now ready to be discharged home 
to continue your recovery. 

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.

Spleen laceration Instructions:

*AVOID contact sports and/or any activity that may cause injury 
to your abdominal area for the next ___ weeks.
 
*If you suddenly become dizzy, lightheaded, feeling as if you 
are going to pass out go to the nearest Emergency Room as this 
could be a sign that you are having internal bleeding from your 
liver or spleen injury.
 
*AVOID any blood thinners such as Motrin, Naprosyn, Indocin, 
Aspirin, Coumadin or Plavix for at least ___ days unless 
otherwise instructed by the MD/NP/PA.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a revision femoral-popliteal bypass. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

MEDICATION:
Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily 
If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows 
every ___ hours throughout the day and night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
When you go home, you may walk and use stairs
You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area 
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 
week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call 
___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

anesthesia and intubated, his chest, abdomen, and lower
extremities were prepped with chlorhexidine and draped in the
usual fashion.  The intraoperative transesophageal
echocardiogram showed that his left ventricular function had
an ejection fraction of 10% to 20%.  He had a dilated right
ventricular cavity with mild global right ventricular free
wall hypokinesis.  He had mild mitral regurgitation and trace
aortic regurgitation.  There was no PFO.

A median sternotomy was made.  The incision was extended a
couple centimeters below the xiphoid process.  The
preperitoneal pocket was created and the pericardium was
opened up.  The patient was fully heparinized prior to
inserting the aortic cannula and a venous cannula into the
right atrial appendage.  We went on bypass.  I elevated the
left ventricular apex and identified the dimpled portion.  I
cored out the LV apex and anchored the apical sewing ring with
pledgeted ___ Ethibond sutures.  BioGlue was then sprayed around
the raw surface and around the suture line.  The pump was then
attached to the apical sewing ring and tied down with a heavy
suture and fastened with a silastic strap for reinforcement.  
The
outflow graft was then connected up to the pump.  A side-biting
clamp was placed on the proximal ascending aorta and the graft
was measured and cut appropriately at a beveled angle.
Longitudinal aortotomy was made and the outflow graft was
then sewn to the aorta with running ___ Prolene sutures.  A
de-airing needle was placed into the graft.  The drive line,
which had been brought out through the left side of the 
abdominal wall, was then connected up to the controller.  We
started at 6000 rpm.  The patient was ventilated.  The
side-biting clamp was released.  As we came down on the
cardiopulmonary bypass machine, we went up on the rpm of the
pump.  There was minimal air seen on the echocardiogram. The
apical ring was in good position. With the assistance from 
the echocardiogram, we adjusted the rpm until the left
ventricular cavity was adequately decompressed.  The
intraventricular septum was midline.  The right ventricular
dysfunction was mild with some inotropic support.  Protamine
was given to reverse heparin.  The cannulas were removed.
Three chest tubes were inserted, one in the left apical/left
pleural space and two in the anterior mediastinum.  A piece of
Gortex tube graft was used to cover the outflow graft. The
pericardium was reapproximated around the aorta and the right
ventricle and the remaining opening was covered with
CorMatrix.  The sternum was closed with stainless steel
wires.  The rectus fascia and the subcutaneous tissues were
closed in 2 layers with running Vicryl sutures.  The skin was
closed with running subcuticular Monocryl sutures.  Prevena
was placed over the incision.  The patient left the
operating room, intubated and in stable condition, on
inotropes and pressors.

with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating diet as

was well controlled.  The patient was discharged home without 
services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the Emergency Department if you develop a fever greater than 101 
F, shaking chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing, pain with 
breathing, cough, a rapid heartbeat, dizziness, severe abdominal 
pain, pain unrelieved by your pain medication, a change in the 
nature or severity of your pain, severe nausea, vomiting, 
abdominal bloating, severe diarrhea, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness, 
swelling from your incisions, or any other symptoms which are 
concerning to you.

Diet: You may have a regular diet as tolerated.

Medication Instructions:
Please refer to the medication list provided with your discharge 
paperwork for detailed instruction regarding your home and newly 
prescribed medications.  
Some of the new medications you will be taking include:
1.  Pain medication: You will receive a prescription for liquid 
oxycodone, an opioid pain medication.  This medication will make 
you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or 
operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities 
while taking these medications. You may also take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol) for pain management; do not exceed 4000 mg per 24 hour 
period.  Do not take your home Percocet when taking the 
oxycodone or Tylenol.
2. Constipation: This is a common side effect of opioid pain 
medication that he received while in the hospital.  If you 
experience constipation, please reduce or eliminate opioid pain 
medication.  You may trial 2 ounces of light prune juice and/or 
a stool softener (i.e. crushed docusate sodium tablets), twice 
daily until you resume a normal bowel pattern.  Please stop 
taking this medication if you develop loose stools. Please do 
not begin taking laxatives including until you have discussed it 
with your nurse or surgeon.
3.  Vitamins/ minerals: You may resume a chewable multivitamin, 
however, please discuss when to resume additional vitamin and 
mineral supplements with your bariatric dietitian.

Activity:
You should continue walking frequently throughout the day right 
after surgery; you may climb stairs.  
You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, but avoid 
performing abdominal exercises or lifting items greater than 10 
to 15 pounds for six weeks.

Wound Care:
You may remove any remaining gauze from over your incisions.  
You will have thin paper strips (Steri-Strips) over your 
incision; please, remove any remaining Steri-Strip seven to 10 
days after surgery.   
You may shower 48 hours following your surgery; avoid scrubbing 
your incisions and gently pat them dry.  Avoid tub baths or 
swimming until cleared by your surgeon. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, cloudy, bloody or foul smelling drainage from the 
incision sites. 
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for up to 24 
months.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent a precipitous spontaneous vaginal 
delivery on ___ complicated by a manual extraction of the 
placenta. EBL was 350cc. She has iron deficiency anemia at 
baseline requiring iron infusions as an outpatient with a 
baseline hct of 30.8. She had some dizziness and BPs ___ 
immediately post-delivery and hct was found to be 23. 
Differential diagnosis included undercall of EBL at time of 
delivery vs vaginal wall or retroperitoneal hematoma A bedside 
ultrasound showed no free fluid in the abdomen and thin 
ultrasound stripe. Exam was reassuring. Platelets and coags were 
wnl. Late on PPD#0 hct trended further down to 20.3. She was 
then transfused 2u pRBCs without issue.

On PPD#1, 6hrs after end of transfusion, her hct had risen 
appropriately to 25.2. Her vitals and exam remained stable for 
the duration of her stay.

She has chronic hypertension at baseline. She was maintained on 
her home labetolol 200mg BID with holding parameters. She had 
baseline PIH labs that were normal, and repeat labs on PPD#0 
were also normal. 

She otherwise underwent an uncomplicated postpartum course. Her 
vaginal bleeding was within normal limits. She tolerated a 
regular diet, voided spontaneously without issue, and ambulated 
independently. By postpartum day 2 after vaginal delivery, she 
was deemed stable for discharge with a plan set for postpartum 
follow up.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Dr. ___ Aneurysm ___

Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:
- Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement
- Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision
- Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy
- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
- Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications
 
Activity:
- Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.
- Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:
- Keep your wound clean and dry.
- Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 
- When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.
- Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.
- You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical
- Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month
- You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:
o Drinking plenty of fluids
o Increasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
o Exercising
o Using over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as 
needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements 
or diarrhea
- Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time
- Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve
- Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area
- Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional
- You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include
o Feeling down or sad
o Irritability, frustration, and confusion
o Distractibility
o Lower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
o Insomnia
o Loneliness
- If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist
- You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation
o More information can be found at ___

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you were having 
abdomen pain and blood in your stool. Your blood numbers 
(hemoglobin) were slightly lower than usual. 

We performed a colonoscopy that showed inflammation called 
colitis. This was likely something called ischemic colitis, 
which occurs when there is low blood pressure to the intestines. 
It may also be infectious. A biopsy was taken to confirm these 
results.

For ischemic colitis, it is important that your blood pressure 
remain stable and not go too low. Because of that, we held your 
losartan and spironolactone. You will also complete a 5 day 
course of antibiotics (ciprofloxacin and metronidazole).

You were stable and discharged home after the procedure.

It was a privilege to care for you in the hospital, and we wish 
you all the best.

Sincerely,

Your ___ Health Team

Discharge Instructions: Brain Tumor

Surgery
 You underwent surgery to debulk a brain lesion from your 
brain. Ultimately, the decision was made to keep you comfortable 
and proceed to a ___ facility for ongoing care. 

What You ___ Experience:
 You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
 You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
 You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
 Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
==========================================
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with history of prostate cancer s/p 
radiation ___ years ago, DLBCL stage IIIA s/p 6 cycles of CHOP in 
___, and hypertension who presented with cough and hypoxemia 
and was found to have pulmonary edema, imaging consistent with 
ILD (previously undiagnosed), and obstructive ___ which had 
likely contributed to volume overload and pulmonary edema 
causing his acute presentation. Foley was placed and he 
auto-diuresed to dry weight with resolution of hypoxemia. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
==========================================
# Hypoxemia
# Interstitial lung disease
# Pulmonary edema
Patient presented with two days of cough and shortness of breath 
with preceding fatigue of about 10 days. He was found to have 
hypoxemia to
mid-80s and admitted for further work-up. CT chest w/o contrast 
showed asymmetric but bilateral reticulation and ground glass 
opacities as well as bronchiectasis and dilation of airways most 
severe in RUL, with LUL relatively spared. These findings were 
felt to be consistent with ILD with both an active inflammatory 
and chronic component. Initial TTE revealed EF 50%, severe pHTN 
(PASP 71), and RV hypertrophy, concerning for chronic pulmonary 
hypertension process. Pulmonary was consulted and recommended 
broad work-up for ILD which was negative including: ___, ANCA,

Scl70, anti-CCP, HIV, aldolase, myositis panel, and respiratory 
viral panel. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis panel was pending at 
time of discharge. The patient initially required ___ NC for 
supplemental O2, which was subsequently able to be weaned off 
with diuresis (see below). After the patient was felt to have 
diuresed to his dry weight, repeat CXR and TTE were obtained 
which showed improvement in pulmonary HTN and lung opacities. 

# Hypertensive emergency
On presentation the patient was noted to have elevated blood 
pressures to 200s/100s. Although he was asymptomatic, he was 
noted to have significant O2 requirement felt to be secondary to 
pulmonary edema. He was started on nitroglycerin gtt titrated to 
SBP 140s-160s, then weaned to labetalol and hydralazine. 
Eventually he was transitioned to a regimen of labetalol and 
amlodipine which good BP control. His home atenolol was held in 
the setting ___ (see below). His blood pressures remained 
stable. 

# Acute kidney injury, post-renal
Baseline creatinine 1.2 in ___. On admission the patient was 
found to have Cr 2.4 which subsequently rose to 3.0. Renal 
ultrasound showed moderate bilateral hydroureteral nephrosis 
consistent with obstruction. Notably the patient has a history 
of prostate cancer and a very enlarged prostate. He did have 
traumatic foley placement and eventually required cystoscopic 
placement of foley by Urology. Afterwards he was noted to have 
significant urine output of ___ daily and subsequent 
improvement in his creatinine. Per Urology, foley remained in 
place at discharge with plan for Urology follow-up. He was 
continued on doxazosin 4mg QHS and finasteride 5mg QD which he 
had recently stopped. 

# Normocytic anemia
Baseline Hb 13.3. The patient presented with Hb at 10.6. Other 
than intermittent hematuria he had no evidence of bleeding. Iron 
studies were consistent with anemia of chronic disease with low 
reticulocyte count indicating inflammatory block. His hemoglobin 
remained stable throughout admission.

# Incontinence

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided handout that details 
instructions and expectations for your post-operative phase as 
made available by your urologist. 

***please keep a log of narcotics (pain pill) used over the week 
and return the log sheet at your follow up appointment. Remember 
to also bring the narcotic prescription bottle WITH YOU for your 
follow up appointment.

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing 
products and supplements that may have blood-thinning effects 
(like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.).  This will be noted in your 
medication reconciliation. 

IF PRESCRIBED (see the MEDICATION RECONCILIATION):
-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  

For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then 
ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
from ALL sources

AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.

-No DRIVING for TWO WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation.

Discharge Instructions:
ILEOSTOMY TAKEDOWN
You were admitted to the hospital after an ileostomy takedown. 
You have recovered from this procedure well and you are now 
ready to return home. 
The muscles of the sphincters have not been used in quite some 
time and you may experience urgency or small amounts of 
incontinence, this should improve. If you do not see improvement 
and you are having symptoms of dehydration (headache, 
lightheadedness, dizziness, dark urine, or dry mouth) please 
call the office or go to the emergency room.   
You have a small wound where the old ileostomy once was. This 
should be covered with a dry gauze dressing.  Please monitor the 
incision for signs and symptoms of infection including: 
increasing redness and pain at the incision site, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a 
fever. If you develop these symptoms please call the office or 
go to the emergency room.
You may shower, let the warm water run over the wound line and 
pat the area dry with a towel, do not rub. Please apply a new 
gauze dressing after showering.
You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. Do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. 
At your post op appointment, your surgical team will clear you 
for heavier exercise.  In the meantime, you may climb stairs, 
and go outside and walk.  Please avoid traveling long distances 
until you speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit.  
It is expected that you will have pain after surgery, this will 
gradually improve over the first week or so you are home.  You 
should continue to take 2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for 
pain every 8 hours around the clock. Please do not take more 
than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or any other medications that 
contain Tylenol such as cold medication. Do not drink alcohol 
while taking Tylenol.  You may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg 
every 8 hours for 7 days, please take Advil with food. If these 
medications are not controlling your pain to a point where you 
can ambulate and perform minor tasks, you should take a dose of 
the narcotic pain medication. Please do not take sedating 
medications or drink alcohol while taking the narcotic pain 
medication.  Do not drive while taking narcotic medications. 
While taking narcotic pain medications you are at risk for 
constipation, please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace. 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care, we wish 
you all the best!

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you.  You were admitted to the 
hospital because of an infection in the bone of your right fifth 
toe.  You are now being discharged after undergoing amputation 
of your right fifth toe.  You are recovering very well.  Please 
follow the below instructions for an uncomplicated recovery:

WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to feel tired.  This might last for ___ weeks.
You should get up out of bed every day with assistance and 
gradually increase your activity each day.  Do not do too much 
right away!

Remember that you should not bear weight on your right forefoot. 
 Some patients who undergo toe amputation fall once they get 
home.  Be very careful when standing, transferring from one 
position to another or walking!  You should ask for help if you 
do not think you can safely do these by yourself!

It is normal to have some swelling surrounding the incision.
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart every ___ hours 
throughout the day.

Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your leg 
elevated.  

It is normal to have a decreased appetite. You might lose your 
taste for food and lose some weight.  Eat small, frequent meals. 
 Your appetite should return with time.  It is important to eat 
nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, 
vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your 
strength and assist in wound healing.
To avoid constipation, eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication.

MEDICATIONS:
Follow your discharge medication instructions below.  These have 
been carefully reviewed by your providers.
You can use Tylenol ___ every 8 hours.  Be aware that there 
are some over-the-counter and prescription medications that 
contain acetaminophen.  Be sure never to consume more than 
3000mg of Tylenol(also known as Acetaminophen) in one day.
Use narcotic pain medication sparingly.  You should require 
smaller amounts and doses of this less often as time goes on.  
NEVER DRIVE OR OPERATE MACHINERY WHILE ON NARCOTIC PAIN  
MEDICATION.  If you are taking narcotics, keep in mind that you 
may become constipated.  You can take over-the-counter stool 
softeners or laxatives to prevent or treat this.

ACTIVITIES:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking pain 
medications.

Do not bear weight on your right forefoot.

You may shower.  Do not directly spray the incision.  Let the 
soapy water run over incision, rinse and pat dry.

CALL THE OFFICE at ___ FOR:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions
Any questions or concerns

rounds of chest compressions were done, 3 rounds of epi and

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ for 
a lap right colectomy for a colonic polyp. She tolerated the 
procedure well without complications (Please see operative note 
for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the 
PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further 
post-operative management. On POD#2 at 1100, code blue was 
called given unresponsiveness. Initially SBPs in ___ by 
palpation. Massive transfusion protocol was activated. BPs 
improved to 130s/40s with 1L NS and 1 unit pRBC. She also 
received Narcan, which didn't help. BPs stabilized, but remained 
altered. Went for pan-CT, which showed no brain bleed, and CT 
torso pending.
Went to OR for ex-lap, and had 1.7L blood (mixed with ascites) 
in abdominal cavity with no obvious site of bleeding. There were 
two areas of oozing: one near gallbladder fossa, and another 
near anastomosis staple line. Both sites were sutured and 
surgifoam applied. Received total of 2u pRBCs, 1u FFP, and a 
___ drain was placed. She did not require pressors, and 
made 400cc of urine.

#hemorrhagic shock: the patient was noted to have a downtrending 
H&H and on POD#2 was non-responsive and transiently hypotensive. 
CODE BLUE was initiated and she was resuscitated with IVF and 
1uPRBC, however labs at this point were notable for a hemoglobin 
of 5. BP improved to normal with resuscitation, and plans were 
made for operative exploration. Given persistent altered mental 
status, a CODE STROKE was initiated and the patient underwent 
imaging that did not reveal any evidence of acute intra-cranial 
injury, and mental status returned to baseline. She was 
subsequently taken to the operating room, where she was noted to 
have generalized venous oozing at the staple line and within an 
area of previous adhesions; 1.7L blood was evacuated and 
hemostasis obtained. She was taken to the ICU for stabilization, 
intubated and sedated. In total, she received 2uPRBC, 2uFFP and 
1uplatelets. She did not require pressors and her UOP remained 
appropriate. On ___ she was extubated uneventfully.

#delirium: in the setting of her ICU stay, the patient developed 
some transient delirium which resolved after two days out of the 
ICU. She got one dose of Haldol overnight in the ICU for this. 

Due to the patients high risk of bleeding, thrombocytopenia and 
liver disease we decided not to send the patient home on 
Lovenox. On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At 
discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, 
voiding, and ambulating with assistance. She will follow-up in 
the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to 
the patient directly prior to discharge. She has adequate follow 
up with Vascular and ENT.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital after a right colectomy for 
surgical management of your colonic polyp. You were taken back 
to the operating room due to bleeding complications. You have 
recovered from this procedure and you are now ready to return 
home.  
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to discharge which is 
acceptable; however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. However, you may 
have loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old 
appearing blood. If you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose 
stool without improvement please call the office or go to the 
emergency room. While taking narcotic pain medications you are 
at risk for constipation, please take an over the counter stool 
softener such as Colace.
 
You have one long vertical surgical incision on your abdomen 
which is closed with internal sutures.  It is important that you 
monitor this areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. You may shower; pat the incisions dry with 
a towel, do not rub. Please do not take a bath or swim until 
cleared by the surgical team.
 
Pain is expected after surgery. This will gradually improve over 
the first week or so you are home.  You should continue to take 
2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around 
the clock. Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 
24hours or any other medications that contain Tylenol such as 
cold medication. Do not drink alcohol while taking Tylenol.  You 
may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every 8 hours for 7 days. 
Please take Advil with food. If these medications are not 
controlling your pain to a point where you can ambulate and 
perform minor tasks, you should take a dose of the narcotic pain 
medication.  Please do not take sedating medications, drink 
alcohol, or drive while taking the narcotic pain medication. 
 
You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. Do not lift greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. 
At your post op appointment, your surgical team will clear you 
for heavier exercise.  In the meantime, you may climb stairs and 
go outside and walk.  Please avoid traveling long distances 
until you speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit.   

 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care, we wish 
you all the best!

Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after 
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well 
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be 
discharged home. 

While you were here some of your electrolytes were low. We 
replaced these daily as needed. One of your electrolytes that 
was low was your calcium. We did an EKG to look at the 
electrical activity of your heart and this was normal. We did 
further labs to find a cause for your low calcium but these came 
back normal. We replaced your calcium and it came back to a 
normal level. 

We consulted the nutrition service while you were here. They 
gave you recommendations for a healthy diet to follow. Please 
continue to follow their recommendations when you leave the 
hospital. 

Please follow these instructions: 

Abdominal instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  We recommend you take 
non-narcotics (i.e. Tylenol, ibuprofen) regularly for the first 
few days post-operatively, and use the narcotic as needed. As 
you start to feel better and need less medication, you should 
decrease/stop the narcotic first.
* Take a stool softener to prevent constipation. You were 
prescribed Colace. If you continue to feel constipated and have 
not had a bowel movement within 48hrs of leaving the hospital 
you can take a gentle laxative such as milk of magnesium.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (tylenol) in 24 
hrs.

* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 12 
weeks.  
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.
* It is safe to walk up stairs.

scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.

days from surgery, you may remove them.

visit.

blood clots after surgery. This risk is highest in the first 
four weeks after surgery. You will be discharged with a daily 
Lovenox (blood thinning) medication. This is a preventive dose

* chest pain or difficulty breathing 
* onset of any concerning symptoms

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital after surgery 
on your leg.   This surgery was to drain a hematoma that formed 
in your right leg. You tolerated the procedure well and are now 
ready to be discharged from the hospital.   Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery.

Vascular Leg Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to except:

It is normal feel tired for ___ weeks after your surgery
It is normal to have leg swelling.  Keep your leg elevated as 
much as possible.  This will decrease the swelling. 
Your leg will feel tired and sore.   This usually passes 
within a few weeks.
Your incision will be sore, slightly raised, and pink.  Any 
drainage should decrease or stop with in the first 2 weeks. 
If you are home, you will likely receive a visit from a 
Visiting Nurse ___.  Members of your health care team will 
discuss this with you before you go home.   

Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

It is very important that you take Aspirin every day!  You 
should never stop this medication before checking with your 
surgeon

Pain Management:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following surgery.  
This pain is often described as soreness. 
You may take Tylenol (acetaminophen ) as needed for pain.   
You will also receive a prescription for stronger pain medicine, 
 if the Tylenol doesnt work, take prescription medicine. 
Narcotic pain medication can be very constipating, please also 
take a stool softner such as Colace.   If constipation becomes a 
problem, your pharmacist can suggest additional over the counter 
medications. 
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets to severe. 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 


Activity:
Do not drive until your surgeon says it is okay and:
-your leg feels strong
-you have stopped taking pain medication and feel you could 
respond in an emergency
Walking is good because it helps your muscles get stronger and 
improves blood flow. Start with short walks.  If you can, go a 
little further each time, letting comfort be your guide.  
Try not to go up and downstairs too much in the first weeks.  
Use stairs only once or twice a day until your incision is fully 
healed and you are back to your usual strength.
Avoid things that may constrict blood flow or put pressure on 
your incision, such as tight shoes, socks or knee highs.
Do not take a tub bath or swim until your staples are removed 
and your wound is healed. 
When you sit, keep your leg elevated to reduce swelling.
If swelling in your leg is getting worse, lie down with your 
leg up on a pillows.  If your swelling continues, please call 
your surgeon.  You may be instructed to use special elastic 
bandages or stockings.
Try not to sit in the same position for a long while.  For 
example, ___ go on a long car ride. 
You may go outside.  But avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
You may resume sexual activity after your incisions are well 
healed.

Your incision

Your incision may be slightly red around the stitches.  This 
is normal.
It is normal to have a small amount of clear or light red 
fluid coming from your incision.
This will decrease and stop in a few days.  If it does not stop, 
or if you have a lot of fluid coming out., please call your 
surgeon.
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery.  Do not let the 
shower spray right on the incision,  Let the soapy water run 
over the incision, then rinse.  Gently pat the area dry.  Do not 
scrub the incision,  Do not apply ointment or lotions to the 
incision.
You do not need to cover the incision if there is no drainage, 
 If there is a small amount of drainage, put a small sterile 
gauze or Bandaid over the incison.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision,  This 
will go away as your wound heals. 
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for 6 months.  
This will help keep the scar from becoming discolored.
Over ___ months, your incision will fade and become less 
prominent.

Diet and Bowels
It is normal to have a decreased appetite.  Your appetite will 
return over time.   Follow a well-balanced, health healthy diet, 
without too much salt and fat. 
Prescription pain medicine might make you constipated.  If 
needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace) or gentle 
laxative (ask your pharmacist for recommendations).
Drinking more fluid may also help.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or having pain 
moving your bowels, call your primary care physician.

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY FOR ADMISSION
___ with ulcerative colitis, HTN, HLD, T2DM and prior strokes 
presents for evaluation after being found to be hyponatremic by 
home ___. Patient was also found to be severely hypothyroid and 
had a urinary tract infection on presentation. Etiology of 
hyponatremia likely due to combination of extrarenal losses from 
diarrhea, SIADH, and hypothyroidism. Blood sodium level was 
slowly increased with IV NS boluses as well as changing tubefeed 
regimen. Salt tabs were also started with resolution of 
hyponatremia. Patient was found to be severely hypothyroid and 
levothyroxine was started with plan to continue titrating up 
levothyroxine dose following discharge. Urine culture in the 
emergency department grew pseudomonas which was sensitive to 
ciprofloxacin and patient completed 3 day course. Patient was 
discharged on salt tabs and modified tubefeed regimen as well as 
50 mcg daily levothyroxine.

ACUTE ISSUES:
===============
# Hyponatremia:
# Diarrhea:
# SIADH:
Na incidentally found to be 123. Uosm >100, UNa<20 on admission, 
consistent with hypovolemia, likely due to diarrhea at home 
(unknown etiology) contributing to extrarenal losses. Patient 
did have antibiotic treatment after arriving at the hospital but 
suspicion for C. diff was low as diarrhea started prior to 
admission. Hypothyroidism possibly contributing as well (see 
below). Noted that duloxetine can cause hyponatremia in the 
elderly, but the time course of hyponatremia did not fit this as 
being a cause. Patient was initially given IV NS with 
appropriately slow response of ~6 mEq/24 hours increase in serum 
Na. Patient was also determined to have a component of SIADH 
with urine Na>40 and urine osm>100 on later urine electrolyte 
check. Tubefeeds were adjusted to have higher solute content and 
minimize free water intake. Salt tabs were started with good 
response. Patient was discharged on salt tabs and new tubefeed 
regimen per nutrition and sodium level on discharge was 135. The 
patient was provided with a script for a lab draw on discharge 
and the need for monitoring was communicated with her outpatient 
provider.

# Hypothyroidism
TSH was checked as part of euvolemic hyponatremia workup. Found 
to be 96 with FT4 1.4. Endocrine was consulted and recommended 
starting levothyroxine at 50 mcg with long term plan to titrate 
up dose. Cosyntropin stim test was performed to rule out adrenal 
insufficiency; result was normal. Additionally, tubefeeds were 
changed to 20 hours a day as levothyroxine absorption is 
disrupted by continuous tubefeeds. TSH and FT4 were rechecked on 
discharge but were pending at discharge. See transitional issues 
for long-term plan regaring levothyroxine.

# Urinary tract infection
Patient with positive urinalysis on admission w/ nitrites and 
___, WBC in urine and mild leukocytosis. Patient was treated with 
3 days of ceftriaxone while urine culture pended. Urine culture 
from ED grew pseudomonas aeruginosa, so patient also received 3 
day course of ciprofloxacin.

# Nutrition
Patient's tubefeed regimens were switched around several times 
this admission as the team pursued tubefeed regimen initially 
that would limit free water and maximize solute, and then had to 
readjust again to make 4 hour gap in the day to administer 
levothyroxine. Patient was discharged on new tubefeed regimen 
per nutrition. Additionally, patient received zinc and ascorbic 
acid repletion to continue on discharge for 11 and 3 additional 
days, respectively

# Skin breakdown
Patient admitted with coccyx and partially on inner thighs. Per 
son, patient had much worse pressure ulcers upon discharge from 
a nursing home she was briefly put in earlier this year. Wound 
care was consulted and their recommendations were followed.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
# Non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes
Home metformin and glipizide were held while in house and 
patient was on humalog sliding scale. Blood glucose levels were 
well controlled with the exception of one day when patient was 
on osmolite - resolved with switch back to glucerna tubefeeds.

# UC
Continued home mesalamine and ursodiol

# Hx of CVA
Continued home asa, statin. Continued home keppra, 
methylphenidate

# GERD: 
Continued home PPI

# Constipation
Continued home bowel reg

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[ ] Several changes were made this admission that could affect 
patient's sodium levels including new tubefeed regimen, starting 
salt tabs, and treating her hypothyroidism. She will need close 
monitoring of her sodium level in the period following 
discharge. The patient was provided with a script for a lab draw 
on discharge. 

[ ] Note that patient has been on duloxetine, which is known to 
cause hyponatremia in the elderly. Though the time course of her 
hyponatremia does not necessarily suggest that this is a factor 
in her hyponatremia, this medication should be noted moving 
forward and one might consider whether this medication is 
actually providing any benefit to her.

[ ] Patient was found to be severely hypothyroid this admission. 
The endocrinologists have recommended the following scheduling 
of tracking thyroid function tests (TFT's) and adjusting 
levothyroxine (Lt4) doses:
-Recheck TFT's on ___ including TSH and free T4 (NOT T4 by 
dialysis). If T4/T3 labs show an increase and she continues to 
tolerate the medication, continue levothyroxine at 50mcg.
- ___ Increase levothyroxine to 75mcg
- ___ Recheck TSH and ___ If absorption is good and TSH begins to respond, then 
increase levothyroxine to 100 mcg. Based on her initial weight, 
goal levothyroxine (1.6x weight in kilos) would be around 122.5.

Dear Ms. ___,
